item.title: Sea level anomalies
item.description:
Global sea level is monitored through a network of tide gages distributed along different coastlines which provide relative sea level measurements and satellite observations that provide also valuable data of global sea level. Satellite measurements started in 1993 and different satellite have been monitoring the sea surface height (ssh). Among the products of these satellite measurements, there is the multimission altimeter satellite gridded ssh data and derived variables computed with respect to a twenty-year mean. The data are processed from all altimeter missions: Jason-3, Sentinel-3A, HY-2A, Saral/AltiKa, Cryosat-2, Jason-2, Jason-1, T/P, ENVISAT, GFO, ERS1/2. The data was previously distributed by Aviso+ and now it’s made available through the Copernicus Marine Service Information here is the link.

In this post, I briefly show how to download, visualise and convert/export time series for further analyses using R.

Data download

There are at least 2 ways to download the data depending on the amount of data you are interested in (geographical and temporal scales).

  1. Using the Copernicus Marine Service website, click on Products and select Sea surface Hight from the parameter Tab (left) then scroll down to the global ocean SSH. From the new opened page, click on Download product (here you will need to create an account and log in to access the download page). From the download page, select the geographical area, the time range and the parameters you are interested in and click data access. However, you are only allowed to download up to 1GB of data at the same time.

  2. Alternatively, if you are interested in downloading the entire records, you can access the files from ftp, here is a code to automate the downloading of the entire data-sets globally from 1993 - to present (it takes time but it does the job!)

The daily SSH data is organised in an ftp folder for each year starting from 1993 to 2017. So I use download.file function from RCurlin a for loop.

# load the libraries
library(RCurl)
library(plyr)

# ftp path of the data (don't foreget to replace the username and password by your credentials)

url <- "ftp://username:password@ftp.sltac.cls.fr/Core/SEALEVEL_GLO_PHY_L4_REP_OBSERVATIONS_008_047/dataset-duacs-rep-global-merged-allsat-phy-l4-v3/"

# Destination folder
dest <- "D:/ssh/"
for (yr in 1993:2018) {
  filenames <- getURL(paste0(url, yr, "/"),
    ftp.use.epsv = FALSE, dirlistonly = TRUE, verbose = TRUE
  )
  filenames2 <- unlist(strsplit(filenames, "\r\n"))
  # Use lapply function and the outputs names are taken from the file names -characters between from 154 to 203-
lapply(
  paste0(url, u, "/", filenames2),
  function(x) download.file(x, paste0(
      "D://ssh//", substr(x, 154, 203)
    ),
    quiet = T, mode = "wb"
    )
)
}

Plot one day of SSH anomalies

To illustrate this I am using just a quick downloaded subset of ssh anomalies data along the Moroccan Atlantic ocean. The row data is in Netcdf format that we need to prepare before making the plot.

# load the necessary packages
library(ncdf4)
library(lubridate)
library(RColorBrewer)
library(tidyverse)
# set path and filename
fname <- "dataset-duacs-rep-global-merged-allsat-phy-l4_1540208137885.nc"
path <- "C:/Dropbox (AbLou)/R-projects/"
vname <- "sla"

# Read the netcdf file
ssh_nc <- nc_open(paste0(path, fname))
# Check the file
print(ssh_nc)
## File C:/Dropbox (AbLou)/R-projects/dataset-duacs-rep-global-merged-allsat-phy-l4_1540208137885.nc (NC_FORMAT_CLASSIC):
## 
##      1 variables (excluding dimension variables):
##         int sla[longitude,latitude,time]   
##             _FillValue: -2147483647
##             comment: The sea level anomaly is the sea surface height above mean sea surface; it is referenced to the [1993, 2012] period; see the product user manual for details
##             coordinates: time latitude longitude 
##             grid_mapping: crs
##             long_name: Sea level anomaly
##             scale_factor: 1e-04
##             standard_name: sea_surface_height_above_sea_level
##             units: m
## 
##      3 dimensions:
##         time  Size:9149
##             axis: T
##             calendar: gregorian
##             long_name: Time
##             standard_name: time
##             units: days since 1950-01-01 00:00:00
##             _CoordinateAxisType: Time
##         latitude  Size:65
##             axis: Y
##             bounds: lat_bnds
##             long_name: Latitude
##             standard_name: latitude
##             units: degrees_north
##             valid_max: 89.875
##             valid_min: -89.875
##             _CoordinateAxisType: Lat
##         longitude  Size:101
##             axis: X
##             bounds: lon_bnds
##             long_name: Longitude
##             standard_name: longitude
##             units: degrees_east
##             valid_max: 359.875
##             valid_min: 0.125
##             _CoordinateAxisType: Lon
## 
##     45 global attributes:
##         Conventions: CF-1.6
##         Metadata_Conventions: Unidata Dataset Discovery v1.0
##         cdm_data_type: Grid
##         comment: Sea Surface Height measured by Altimetry and derived variables
##         contact: servicedesk.cmems@mercator-ocean.eu
##         creator_email: servicedesk.cmems@mercator-ocean.eu
##         creator_name: CMEMS - Sea Level Thematic Assembly Center
##         creator_url: http://marine.copernicus.eu
##         date_created: 2018-06-14T20:10:32Z
##         date_issued: 2018-06-14T20:10:32Z
##         date_modified: 2018-06-14T20:10:32Z
##         geospatial_lat_max: 37.375
##         geospatial_lat_min: 21.375
##         geospatial_lat_resolution: 0.25
##         geospatial_lat_units: degrees_north
##         geospatial_lon_max: -5.875
##         geospatial_lon_min: -30.875
##         geospatial_lon_resolution: 0.25
##         geospatial_lon_units: degrees_east
##         geospatial_vertical_max: 0
##         geospatial_vertical_min: 0
##         geospatial_vertical_positive: down
##         geospatial_vertical_resolution: point
##         geospatial_vertical_units: m
##         history: 2018-06-14 20:10:34Z: Creation
##         institution: CLS, CNES
##         keywords: Oceans > Ocean Topography > Sea Surface Height
##         keywords_vocabulary: NetCDF COARDS Climate and Forecast Standard Names
##         license: http://marine.copernicus.eu/web/27-service-commitments-and-licence.php
##         platform: Altika Drifting Phase, Cryosat-2, Haiyang-2A Geodetic Phase, Jason-3, Sentinel-3A
##         processing_level: L4
##         product_version: 4.0.0
##         project: COPERNICUS MARINE ENVIRONMENT MONITORING SERVICE (CMEMS)
##         references: http://marine.copernicus.eu
##         software_version: 6.1
##         source: Altimetry measurements
##         ssalto_duacs_comment: The reference mission used for the altimeter inter-calibration processing is Topex/Poseidon between 1993-01-01 and 2002-04-23, Jason-1 between 2002-04-24 and 2008-10-18, OSTM/Jason-2 between 2008-10-19 and 2016-06-25, Jason-3 since 2016-06-25.
##         standard_name_vocabulary: NetCDF Climate and Forecast (CF) Metadata Convention Standard Name Table v37
##         summary: SSALTO/DUACS Delayed-Time Level-4 sea surface height and derived variables measured by multi-satellite altimetry observations over Global Ocean.
##         time_coverage_duration: P1D
##         time_coverage_end: 2018-01-18T00:00:00Z
##         time_coverage_resolution: P1D
##         time_coverage_start: 2018-01-18T00:00:00Z
##         title: DT merged all satellites Global Ocean Gridded SSALTO/DUACS Sea Surface Height L4 product and derived variables
##         History: Translated to CF-1.0 Conventions by Netcdf-Java CDM (CFGridWriter2)
## Original Dataset = dataset-duacs-rep-global-merged-allsat-phy-l4; Translation Date = 2018-10-22T11:35:37.988Z

Our variable has three dimensions longitude x latitude x time. A slice of data represent one time step, so we are going to extract one slice for a given time and convert it to a date frame with long, lat and shh values so that we can plot the ssh for one time step.

# Long and lat
lon <- ncvar_get(ssh_nc, "longitude") - 360
nlon <- dim(lon)
lat <- ncvar_get(ssh_nc, "latitude")
nlat <- dim(lat)
# get time
time <- ncvar_get(ssh_nc, "time")
ntime <- dim(time)
head(time)
## [1] 15706 15707 15708 15709 15710 15711
# the time step represented by time-since units, so we need to conevrt it to readable units
start_date <- ymd_hms("1950-01-01 00:00:00", tz = "UTC")
time2 <- days(time) + start_date
# get the ssh variable data
ssh <- ncvar_get(ssh_nc, vname)
# get ssh for the time step 1 which corresponds to 1993-01-01
s <- 1
ssh_slice <- ssh[, , s]
# check the dimension
dim(ssh_slice)
## [1] 101  65
# Now you can plot a quick map if you want
image(lon, lat, ssh_slice, col = brewer.pal(10, "RdBu"))

# Create a dataframe for this signle time step
ssh_vec <- data_frame(ssh = as.vector(ssh_slice))
## Warning: `data_frame()` is deprecated, use `tibble()`.
## This warning is displayed once per session.
coord_df <- expand.grid(lon = lon, lat = lat)
ssh_df <- bind_cols(coord_df, ssh_vec)

We can put these last lines of code in a for loop to save each separate time step in a separate dataframe if needed.

slices <- 1:ntime
for (s in slices) {
  ssh_slice <- ssh[, , s] # s=1
  # Creat a dataframe 
  ssh_vec <- data_frame(ssh = as.vector(ssh_slice))
  ssh_df <- bind_cols(coord_df, ssh_vec)
  write_delim(ssh_df, paste0(time2[s], ".txt"))

Plot the ssh on a map

Using leaflet

library(raster)
library(leaflet)
# convert th DF to ratser
r <- rasterFromXYZ(ssh_df, crs = CRS("+init=EPSG:4326"))
# colors 
colrs <- colorRamps::matlab.like2(10)
pal <- colorNumeric(colrs, values(r), na.color = "transparent")
# the map
leaflet() %>%
  addTiles() %>%
  addRasterImage(r, colors = pal, opacity = 0.8) %>%
  addLegend(pal = pal, values = values(r), title = "ssh")

Using ggplot

pal2 <- colorRamps::matlab.like2(10)

ggplot() +
  theme_bw() +
  geom_tile(data = ssh_df, aes(x = lon, y = lat, fill = ssh)) +
  borders("world", fill = "grey50",colour = "grey50") +
  scale_fill_gradientn(
    colours = pal2, limits = c(-0.24, 0.2), name = "ssh",
    na.value = "white", guide = guide_colorbar(barheight = 15)
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(limits = c(-30, -5), expand = c(0, 0)) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(20, 36), expand = c(0, 0))
## Warning: Removed 842 rows containing missing values (geom_tile).

item.title: Contribution of Tropical Cyclones to Rainfall at the Global Scale
Contribution of Tropical Cyclones to Rainfall at the Global Scale
Example Talk
item.description:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.

Slides can be added in a few ways:

  • Create slides using Academic’s Slides feature and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.

Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.

item.title: Cycling time
item.description:
My father in law is a cyclist and he usually cycle from his home located in Bry-sur-marne in Paris to the surrounding towns and localities. So I wanted to help him by a simple visualization of the cycling time from his home to different localities in a radius of 100km. I used Shiny which is an open source R package that make it easy to build interactive web applications using R. So here is the breakdown of what I did:

1. Finding the different localities in a radius of 100Km from Bryan’s home:

For this, I used the package geonames which is an interface to the GeoNames global geographical database. To be able to use the library functions you need a username by creating an account using Geonames website.
I use the GNfindNearbyPlaceName function that take 5 arguments lat, lng, radius, search, and maxRows. For this example I will use just 10 max rows representing 10 localities surrounding my location (i.e. 48.828583, 2.508224)

# load the package
library(geonames)
# set your geonames username
options(geonamesUsername = "khouakhi")
# In this example
loc1 <- GNfindNearbyPlaceName(48.828583, 2.508224,
  radius = "100",
  maxRows = "10", style = "MEDIUM"
)
head(loc1, n = 3)                            
##   adminCode1     lng distance geonameId         toponymName countryId fcl
## 1         11 2.52488  1.61759   3029706       Bry-sur-Marne   3017382   P
## 2         11 2.49366   1.7245   3027105 Champigny-sur-Marne   3017382   P
## 3         11 2.48255  2.08969   2990265    Nogent-sur-Marne   3017382   P
##   population countryCode                name           fclName
## 1      16226          FR       Bry-sur-Marne city, village,...
## 2      76726          FR Champigny-sur-Marne city, village,...
## 3      31236          FR    Nogent-sur-Marne city, village,...
##   adminCodes1.ISO3166_2 countryName
## 1                   IDF      France
## 2                   IDF      France
## 3                   IDF      France
##                                       fcodeName    adminName1      lat
## 1                               populated place Île-de-France 48.83811
## 2                               populated place Île-de-France 48.81642
## 3 seat of a third-order administrative division Île-de-France 48.83669
##   fcode
## 1   PPL
## 2   PPL
## 3 PPLA3

Basically all that we need from this data frame is the longitude, latitude and locality names. The function returns also the euclidean distance between two locations so let’s keep the distance column as well.

loc2 <- loc1[c("name", "lng", "lat", "distance")]
head(loc2)
##                   name     lng      lat distance
## 1        Bry-sur-Marne 2.52488 48.83811  1.61759
## 2  Champigny-sur-Marne 2.49366 48.81642   1.7245
## 3     Nogent-sur-Marne 2.48255 48.83669  2.08969
## 4           Champignol  2.5056 48.80865  2.22481
## 5 Le Perreux-sur-Marne     2.5    48.85  2.45703
## 6    Joinville-le-Pont 2.47458 48.82538  2.49615
# transform the longitude and latitude from character to numeric
loc2[c(2, 3, 4)] <- lapply(loc2[c(2, 3, 4)], as.numeric)
sapply(loc2, class)
##        name         lng         lat    distance 
## "character"   "numeric"   "numeric"   "numeric"

2. Finding the cyling distance and time:

Now that we got the localities, we will use the ggmap package to access distances from the Google Maps API, specifically we are going to use the mapdist function that returns distances in Km and miles but also time in hours and minutes.

library(gmapsdistance)
library(stringr)
# First let's add the word "France" the localitie names
loc2$name <- paste0(loc2$name, "+", "France")
# add (+) in white spaces to allow google to serach for the localities
loc2$name <- str_replace_all(loc2$name, pattern = " ", repl = "+")
# create a loop to calculate cycling distance and time from the home location to every town.
mylist <- list()
home_adress <- "101+Quai+Louis+Ferber+94360+Bry-sur-Marne+France"
for (n in loc2$name) {
  dist <- gmapsdistance(
    origin = home_adress, destination = n,
    mode = "bicycling", key = "your key"
  )

  mylist[[n]] <- c(n, dist[[2]] / 1000, dist[[1]] / 60)
}
results <- as.data.frame(do.call(rbind, mylist))

Now let’s get rid of the irrelevant columns

row.names(results) <- NULL
# rename the the columns
names(results)[1] <- "name"
names(results)[2] <- "distance"
names(results)[3] <- "minutes"
# change the class of distance and time variables to numeric
results$name <- as.character(results$name)
results$distance <- as.numeric(as.character(results$distance))
results$minutes <- as.numeric(as.character(results$minutes))
# convert distances to kms
results$distance <- results$distance

Now we add the coordinates by merging the two tables loc3 and result1.

results$lat <- as.numeric(loc2$lat)
results$lng <- as.numeric(loc2$lng)
time_df <- results

It seems like there is a false value in the cycling distance to La Maltourn?e row #7 (?a a mal tourn? :D), and that can happen when 2 different locations have the same name. So here, I suggest to order the returned cycling distances and compare them with the euclidean distances or you can plot the cycling and the euclidean distances to see potential errors then you can remove or correct them. For this example we are going to remove the row number 7.

time_df <- time_df[c(-7,-4),]

3. Visualize the locations using leaflet and shiny:

Shiny applications need 2 components the user interface ui.R and server side server.R

#load the two libraries
library(shiny)
library(leaflet)
 
ui <- bootstrapPage(
  tags$style(type = "text/css", "html, body {width:100%;height:100%}"),
  leafletOutput("mymap", width = "100%", height = "100%"), # here we show the map in 100% of the page
  # here we add a slider to the map in order to select different cycling times
  absolutePanel(
    top = -60, left = 150,
    sliderInput("min", h2("Select time"), 5, 30,
      value = 30, step = 2
    )
  )
)
#----------------------------server side -------------------------------
server <- function(input, output) {
  # Filter data based on selections from the slider
  output$mymap <- renderLeaflet({
    sub_data <- time_df[time_df$minutes <= input$min, ]
    # palette color of the displayed points
    pal <- colorNumeric(
      palette = colorRamps::matlab.like2(5),
      domain = sub_data$minutes
    )
    leaflet(sub_data) %>%
      # Base map, here I choose the dark map from Carto
      addTiles(
        urlTemplate = "http://{s}.basemaps.cartocdn.com/dark_all/{z}/{x}/{y}.png",
        attribution = '©<ahref="http://www.openstreetmap.org/copyright">OpenStreetMap</a>&co                               py; <ahref="http://cartodb.com/attributions">CartoDB</a>',
        layerId = NULL, group = NULL, options = tileOptions()
      ) %>%
      # The markers for localities
      addCircleMarkers(~ lng, ~ lat,
        stroke = T, radius = 2,
        opacity = 1, fill = TRUE,
        color = pal(sub_data$minutes),
        fillColor = pal(sub_data$minutes),
        popup = ~ as.character(sub_data$minutes)
      ) %>%

      # The marker for the home coordinates
      addMarkers(2.508224, 48.828583) %>%
      # We also add a legend to help visualize time
      addLegend(
        pal = pal, values = ~ minutes, opacity = 2,
        title = "Time (minutes)", position = "topleft"
      )
  })
}

shinyApp(ui, server)

4. Example with hundreds of lacations:

So this is just an example of 10 localities to illustrate what I did, if you want to see how does it look with hundreds of location here is the link to the shiny app.

item.title: Attribution of annual maximum sea levels to tropical cyclones at the global scale
Slides
item.description:
Welcome to Slides

Academic

Features

  • Efficiently write slides in Markdown
  • 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides
  • Supports speaker notes
  • Mobile friendly slides

Controls

  • Next: Right Arrow or Space
  • Previous: Left Arrow
  • Start: Home
  • Finish: End
  • Overview: Esc
  • Speaker notes: S
  • Fullscreen: F
  • Zoom: Alt + Click
  • PDF Export: E

Code Highlighting

Inline code: variable

Code block:

porridge = "blueberry"
if porridge == "blueberry":
    print("Eating...")

Math

In-line math: $x + y = z$

Block math:

$$ f\left( x \right) = \;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$

Fragments

Make content appear incrementally

{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}

Press Space to play!

One Two Three

A fragment can accept two optional parameters:

  • class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS)
  • weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears

Speaker Notes

Add speaker notes to your presentation

{{% speaker_note %}}
- Only the speaker can read these notes
- Press `S` key to view
{{% /speaker_note %}}

Press the S key to view the speaker notes!

  • Only the speaker can read these notes
  • Press S key to view

Themes

  • black: Black background, white text, blue links (default)
  • white: White background, black text, blue links
  • league: Gray background, white text, blue links
  • beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links
  • sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links
  • night: Black background, thick white text, orange links
  • serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links
  • simple: White background, black text, blue links
  • solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links

Custom Slide

Customize the slide style and background

{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}}
{{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}}
{{< slide class="my-style" >}}

Custom CSS Example

Let’s make headers navy colored.

Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:

.reveal section h1,
.reveal section h2,
.reveal section h3 {
  color: navy;
}

Questions?

Ask

Documentation
